body: I will open a new issue regarding this as soon as I have more information about it. Thank you!

I'll attempt a self-answer based on some experimentation I've been doing, but please tell me I'm wrong if you know otherwise:

The various scheduled instances of a task X are _always_ attempted serially; at the moment, no setting is available to change this. `depends_on_past` sounds like it might do it, but that setting only controls whether a later instance of the task can be scheduled if the prior one has been attempted but _failed_, not whether the task's instances can be run in parallel.

As such, my initial question doesn't make sense. Only one instance of a task will be scheduled to run at a time, and from there it's simply a matter of whether the sensor triggers or not. This does mean, though, that if you have a sensor that never triggers for some reason, your schedule will be totally blocked by that. So that may mean that airflow isn't really designed for passively waiting for something to happen so much as it is for actively checking for things to do on a schedule.

As a design consideration: if an early task in a DAG is able to determine that there's nothing to do when its schedule rolls around, it would be nice to be able to quickly mark the rest of that scheduled DAG as complete when it makes sense to do so. Perhaps this could be signaled by a "skipped" status, along with mechanisms for allowing downstream tasks to determine their own behavior based on the completion statuses of their upstreams. Food for future thought, unless that's something you guys have already considered and discarded, in which case I'd love to hear more about why.

Not sure, the sphinx automagic works out of class doctrings, not object content. 

But it would be easy to put something together in the DAG object that would gather the `doc_md` string from the DAG object and all the tasks in the DAG and put together some a raw html page.

You're right, as it is now the scheduler won't parallelize or fill in holes. Note that `airflow backfill` does though. The way the scheduler operates is documented here:

http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/scheduler.html

`depends_on_past` keeps from scheduling forward after a failure. And forces sequential execution for backfills (who do parallelize not `depends_on_past` tasks).

Adding a `skipped` or `upstream_failed` status as you suggested would allow for non `depends_on_past` tasks to move forward without changing the current scheduler logic much. I haven't done it yet because I may want this status to be virtual, but it requires more complexity in the scheduler and could affect the scheduler's weight on the metadata database and cycling time. We like for the scheduler to run every minute, even with 10k+ tasks which could grow 10x over the next few years. 

The `upstream_failed` status is probably the way to go, though since the scheduler never moves back to fill in holes, it would require running backfill commands to fill in holes left behind. Maybe once we have a UI wizard to do that it won't matter much.

I also may want to trigger the current latest schedule regardless of what the DAG is up to, that brings back the problem around filling holes.

This is a little beyond me, but I'd love to know how to encapsulate the processes, let me know if you have pointers. 

We une chef->runit->sv and some operations have been problematic, notably when running a multi-thread tornado web server and trying to restart it with `sv`, processes aren't killed like they should.

I see the case for a branch operator, though we tend to wire things down different path by using an attribute of the data, and an empty batch typically never happens except if there is a problem.

An easy implementation would be to essentially derive the `PythonOperator` into a `BranchPythonOperator`, and have the assumption that the `python_callable` returns the name of the branch to take, namely the task_id of the direct downstream task to follow. Then this operator would set a failed status on all the directly downstream task_ids not returned.
Thanks!
I wrote a quick sketch of what it may look like in this branch https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/compare/branch_python_operator?expand=1 but haven't tested it, let me know what you think.

Airflow assumes that you are running batch jobs on a schedule. As you see this is deeply rooted in the platform.

I can see how people would be interested use a workflow engine outside of a schedule, say based on when chunks of data show up, or when some other systems tells it to. It's not impossible to do so. The key would be to disregard the scheduler (by not firing it up, or setting the tasks as `adhoc=True`), and to think of `execution_date` as some sort of run_id.

Some elements from the UI won't make sense, but Airflow will still do its thing as a workflow engine.

Thanks for the explanation.

Please evaluate if the docs should have some comment added to explain the use of the start_date, I can imagine others may have similar problems figuring out where it appeared from.

So what I understood:
- "airflow test" allows you to run a single task from a dag. It will actually execute the task locally, but it does not leave logs or update the database that the test was run. I don't know what purpose start_date serves here.
- "airflow run" is used to run a single task through the scheduler (does start_date here mean "run for a particular date?".  I just see the current date in the logs ) 
- "airflow backfill" is used to populate the schedule with records to run tasks from a dag in the correct order, respecting the dependencies. Here the start_date and end_date mean the date range for which to schedule the dag with an indicated interval.

The use of the 'date' parameter without a time part also implies that the dag's are intended to be complex batch jobs that run once per day. Is this correct?
- If a task failed and it is rerun ( "airflow run"?  ) and it succeeds along with the rest of the dag, then in the end airflow reports "all green" for the task on a particular day. You can rerun tasks, but they will just be rerun in the same 'day' context, so it does not make sense.
- corner case: If you have a dag that failed and work up to 1am to resolve it, how does the task show up?  As the "start_date" with which it ran, or just using the current date of the machine?  Is airflow clever enough to consider it part of the previous day's run ( in the logs, etc? ). Does it make sense to try to resolve issues after midnight with airflow?
- When writing airflow operators and tasks, should one use the 'start_date'/'end_date' as input parameter for the work or can any task just use the current machine date / time?  This is a very important decision, because it makes results reproducible (or not). 

I noticed that if you use 'backfill' to create jobs to run, it will also create historic records for that. So if you specify start_date from 2015-01-01, it will create records for every date up to now and run them in the scheduler.

I have made some changes to the tutorial so that it follows the code presented at the top.
I hope it clears some things up.
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/89
fixed.

Notes and answers:
- `start_date` is mostly used by the scheduler (`airflow scheduler`) to know where to start running from for each task. If you commit a new task to your DAG, the scheduler will attempt to run that task starting on that date. Also for tasks that are `depends_on_past==True`, we don't care about that flag for the `start_date`
- Much like `airflow test`, `airflow run` allows you to trigger a single "task instance" with a set of options documented in the CLI doc and displayable by running `airflow run -h`. It cares about dependencies, and records its success/failure in the DB

The assumption is that your DAG has a start_date and a schedule_interval. If you have a schedule_interval of `timedelta(hours=1)`, the scheduler will schedule your DAG to run every hour. The state is recorded for each task instance, which is a task for a specific schedule. The "_date" params receive a `datetime.datetime` in the API and a parsable datetime string in the CLI. You can use `2015-01-01`, or `2015-01-01T00:00` or `2015-01-01T01:00` in the CLI, anything that the dateutils lib will parse, that matches your schedule.
Created a pull request with a proposal on making this clearer.  Most of my confusion was related by not picking up the difference between "execution_date" and "start_date". Now it all makes sense.
@rijuk, What you are looking for is the parameter `wait_for_downstream`. A run for a task instance will then only happen if previous runs of the downstream tasks are complete.

The `requests` lib is already a dependency for Airflow, you can see it both in the `requirements.txt` and the `setup.py`, it's a great library.

Airflow tasks are expected to be synchronous, or made so by writing some sort of sleep/check routine in your operator. It's also expected to raise an exception as a way to communicate an error.

It may be tricky to generalize an HttpOperator since all systems expect different endpoints, payload and return different results. Using a PythonOperator that uses the requests lib is the quick way to do this. Maybe an HttpSensor would be generic enough, receiving an enpoint, payload and a regex to match in the response.

I don't know much about `remap`, but maybe a RemapOperator would make more sense. In general, it's probably a better approach, so that instead of receiving generic `enpoint` and `payload`, it can receive something more meaningful like `job_name`, `parameters_dict` or whatever makes sense for that specific external system.

A side note about hooks, they use the Connection model to store connection information as opposed to hard-coding it in script. It may be nice to have a thin HttpHook that would retrieve that info from the DB and acts as some thin wrapper around the requests lib. I'm not 100% on this though, it may not add a whole lot of value (vs confusion)...

"A run for a task instance will then only happen if previous runs of the **directly** downstream tasks of that task are **succesful**."

If you want to force the completion of the entire DAG, you'll need to put a trigger (say you could land a dummy trigger file in HDFS or S3) at the very end of all the tasks in your DAG, and use a sensor at the very beginning of your DAG (waiting for that that trigger file to show up in HDFS or S3).

So I put something preliminary together of a hook and a sensor to get an idea of the complexity. You can see this development branch at:

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/compare/master...gtoonstra:http_protocol_sensor

I agree, the flavours of what's written with HTTP is too rich to create anything that is generic enough and attempts in such generic approaches usually start to pollute other areas with logic, for example here proliferation of logic into the DAG's. 

In the branch, the hook raises exceptions, but I think most of those should be moved to the operator instead. This is based on the assumption that the operator class decides on success or failure based on the responses of the hook, not the hook itself. In cases of database when a db was expected and didn't exist, the hook is allowed to raise exceptions.

Then all we need probably for now is a SimpleHttpOperator, which is limited to the following:
- it fails or succeeds on the return code only, not on the response content.
- it only supports a 'one-shot' call, no cookies, sessions or conversations, so no calls in a sequence.
- maybe add a 'regex' on the "GET" call to check the state of the object beyond the return code (existence).  
- it has a timeout and never uses a persistent connection.
- only supports basic auth of login and password.

Anything beyond this simple use requires a specific operator:
- file upload/download over http, special auth schemes, http conversations and sessions, special mime-types, etc.

So the remap operator probably falls into the latter category.

Check out the `provide_context` flag in the PythonOperator documentation.
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/code.html#airflow.operators.PythonOperator

The idea is that when your flip that to `True`, I pass the whole context to the call as kwargs. The context is basically everything defined here:
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/code.html#macros

```
def foo(my_param, ds, task, *args, **kwargs):
    print(my_param) # that's your param, you can have as many as you want
    print(ds) # this comes from the context
    print task.task_id # task is a reference to the task object, coming from the context
    print(kwargs.keys()) # shows all the keys in the context not explicitly defined in the function header
```

I think @artwr has a PythonScriptOperator that would receive text or a `.py` file as an input, but it's not in the repo. I prefer the `PythonOperator` approach, I think it makes the code more dynamic and cleaner.

What I'm actually trying to do is template SQL and do some interaction with a db within a PythonOperator - I'm not actually reading/templating `.py` files.

I'm trying to pass the `.sql` template to my PythonOperator and use the rendered version within my operators function (calling out to a postgres hook infact). Is that possible?

Oh interesting. You may be able to call the task's render_template method from your `python_callable`.
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/models.py#L1156

```
def foo(*args, **kwargs):
    task = kwargs['task']
    sql  "TEST: {{ ds }}"
    logging.info(task.render_template(sql, kwargs))
```

Could this be done better?

```
def check_function(ds, **kwargs):
    task = kwargs['task']
    task.__class__.template_ext = ('.sql',)
    rendered_sql = task.render_template(kwargs['sql_template'], kwargs)

    redshift_hook = PostgresHook(postgres_conn_id=kwargs['redshift_connection_id'])
    rec_set = redshift_hook.get_records(rendered_sql)
    # Do some stuff with the record set here.
    logging.info(rec_set)

check_task = PythonOperator(
    task_id='check_task',
    python_callable=check_function,
    provide_context=True,
    params=schema_mapping,
    op_kwargs={'sql_template': 'my_templated_sql.sql',
               'redshift_connection_id': 'redshift_analytics'},
    dag=dag)
```

Incase you cant tell, Python isn't my most comfortable language...
Changes made.

I'm surprised this actually works. You could alter your function to expect sql (templated) as a `str` instead of the sql file location. This would avoid you relying on jinja/airflow internal magic to resolve the file's content. So a good old `open()` there making sure you use a relative path to `__file__` allows you to get rid of the `task.__class__.template_ext` affectation.

Now I'd be careful in your function header of defining `ds` or anything else out of the airflow context because it will strip it out of `kwargs` as kwargs is the placeholder for all non-defined keyword args. Then `ds` doesn't make it through in the `render_template` call. So I'd remove `ds` from the header and get it out of `kwargs` (like `task`). `sql_template` though isn't part of the airflow context, so that one you can have in the header.

@mistercrunch can probably provide a more detailed explanation, but here is my take : 

The way our ETL is setup we use `execution_date` as the date corresponding to the data we want to process (There are a few exceptions, but it is mostly true). In this schema, the task for July 1st does not run on July 1st, because all of the data dependencies have not usually landed yet. We wait until that `schedule_interval` is over and then start processing the data. 
In your example, it means that the daily task for July 1st will actually kick off in the first seconds of July 2nd when this condition is met.

I hope this helps.

I just added a note in the docs to clarify this here http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/scheduler.html:

```
Note that if you run a DAG on a schedule_interval of one day, the run stamped 2016-01-01 will be trigger soon after 2016-01-01T23:59. In other words, the job instance is started once the period it covers has ended.
```

Most likely you want to stamp your partitions with `2016-01-01` for the period covering `2016-01-01 - 2016-01-01T23:59:59`, and you want the job that processes that period to be trigger soon after `2016-01-02`. That's how Airflow does it anyways.

Lambda function introduced too. I eventually decided to return the entire response, because how you grab content differs per response type. This way, there's also access to the status_code, which may be slightly different 200=OK is generic, but for a POST it sometimes is 201[CREATED]. I called it response_check because of that. I believe the original request object is also available.

If space is too limited, it's possible to pass in a regular function instead, which will make code easier to read for complex check logic.

Awesome! I think this is solid as far as I can tell. A few details:
- I'd throw `endpoint` in `template_fields` for sensor as well. `template_fields` is a bad name for this feature, but the idea is that sometime between the `__init__` and the `execute` method is run, the object attributes in that list get templated. So say if someone would want a date in their endpoint they would have to use templating for that, as in `endpoint = "/apiv2/user/getmodified/{{ execution_date.isoformat()[:10].replace("-", "") }}"`
- add an entry in `docs/code.rst` for your 2 operators and hook to show up in the API part of the documentation
- a unit test would be nice in `airflow/tests/core.py`

Another thought (outside the scope of this PR) is around authentication. I read the `requests` library part about sessions and authentication and it seem like people could graft that onto the hook you wrote eventually to support different types of authentication.

Is this what you want: `{{ execution_date.strftime('%s') }}`?
I'm not sure whether this works `{{ task_instance.start_date.strftime('%s') }}`, but should be very close to  `{{ datetime.now().strftime('%s') }}`

I have been using the following for one of my dags where the API requires the same. You could define the function in the DAG definition and then add it to the params for instance : 

```
def dt_to_epoch(dt):
    """
    Converts a date_stamp to epoch
    """
    epoch = datetime.datetime(1970,1,1)
    return int((dt - epoch).total_seconds())


params = {
    "dt_to_epoch": dt_to_epoch
}

aggregate_data_spark_job = BashOperator(
    task_id='aggregate_data_spark_job',
    bash_command="ssh -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa_spark root@10.10.2.157 '. /root/.bash_profile; /root/run_aggregation.sh --start_ts {{ params.dt_to_epoch(end_date) }}'" ,
    dag=dag)
```

It is a little bit of a dirty way to define your own macros inline. I am also confused by your use of `start_date` and `end_date` for any run. Most runs, unless you are doing a backfill, the `date` parameter of interest is the `execution_date`, and `start_date == end_date ==  execution_date`, which corresponds for us to the day of data we want to process regardless of when it actually runs.

Let me know if that helps any.

Start_datetime will essentially be the date at midnight, and end_datetime will be the time 24 hours later, both expressed in epoch seconds. My Spark job will take this start and end time and compute some aggregates.

I fetched your branch to run some tests and ended changing things around a bit. The main thing was the missing `force=True` in the operator `run` call. Without `force=True`, the operator doesn't re-run as it knows it has succeeded in the past.

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/d0f16b103b0131236b1d8ad6b9fb1237855dcad9

I think everything else look fine at this point, if you want to keep iterating you can bring this commit to your PR, or I can just merge my local branch as is. I think you get "credited" for your commits in any case.

Yes, this is confusing in the current state. If you happen to be running an `airflow scheduler`, it will monitor your `DAGS_FOLDER` and keep the list up to date.

There's an hidden endpoint at `/admin/airflow/refresh_all` that will refresh the web server's DagBag from scratch.

Also note that if you run the web server in debug mode `airflow webserver --debug`, it will refresh your dags as you update them, though there are limitations here.

The challenge is that in our environment we have multiple multi-threaded server, and that each thread has its own DagBag. With many DAGs, some very large, refreshing the DagBags in the scope of a web request is a bad idea. Anyhow, we'll have 100% stateless web servers soon as we move to run everything off of serialized, versioned DAGs that live in the DB. This may be a 2.0 kinda thing.
Thanks!

@adambom,

We needed and still need to support different config file formats than the ones supported by boto, hence our roundabout way of doing this, though I should probably reuse the facilities provided by boto when parsing the file formats it understands.

It is also possible to store the credentials in the extras of the airflow connection. See https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/hooks/S3_hook.py#L82-84.

I will work on a way to fall back on environment variables, but because of our need to use several sets of credentials environment variables could not override values provided in the Airflow connections.

You need to pass your params dict to either the DAG or the task constructor. As in:

```
dag = DAG('test_email', default_args=default_args, params=params)
```

or in

```
send_email_notification_flow_successful = EmailOperator(
    task_id='send_email_notification_flow_successful',
    to="sanand@agari.com",
    subject='custom email from airflow',
    html_content="{{ params['foo'](execution_date) }}",
    params=params,
    dag=dag)
```

Note that the DAG level params get passed to all tasks, and that when keys are common task level params take precedence as over the DAG level params.

Cool. Thanks.
-s

This should fix it:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/4afa2ab4c98d91d52beb89cdcad80979843a9aba
If the dependencies aren't met, the task won't execute and record any state. It will print something about the reason it isn't running in the log file though. Is that the case?

Yes, it is.  I misunderstood. I thought in the checking of dependencies, `airflow run` ensure that upstream tasks also get run.  Evidently, that is not the case.  It seems that `airflow run` behaves more like `airflow test` and less like `airflow backfill`.  I think what I want to do in order to test a whole DAG, "from soup to nuts" is to use `airflow backfill`.  I'm curious what the use cases for `airflow test` and `airflow run` are.

A hook is basically a connection to some system. So an operator and a sensor would use a "hook"  to connect to hive to execute query "X", which effects some update (operator) or checks on the results of some rows (sensor). I just finished a pull request for a new http operator, which can talk to many HTTP-based systems. An operator would usually use POST/PUT or DELETE (through the hook) and the sensor would usually use a "GET" request. 

Most hooks require a connection declaration. Rather than encoding that into every hook itself, there's a connections tab on the admin menu (of the webserver), where you can configure what ops and sensors connect to. So that way you keep username/pw and host configs out of the way of code. In the DAG you can then still refer to specific connection-id's.
